Hermann Nitsch

Artist and the most famous figure in Viennese Actionism of the 1960s and 70s. Creator of the Orgien Mysterien Theater, where he performed over 130 actions that are radical even by the standards of the post-war avant-garde. The key themes in his work are victimhood, death and rebirth, and they are always expressed in an extremely naturalistic form.

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. An interactive production based on work with Big Data

The play is about how the Internet turns out to be a place, a way of producing and recognizing statements about complex experiences. What can't be contained or endured, from violence to boredom, becomes written and partly public. The Internet as a space and tool allows such statements to take place and become weighty, meaningful, and effective.
Working with various online materials, studying publications in social networks, participants and participants will be able to form a text for reading under the guidance of moderators.

You will be engaged in digital ethnography. Just as anthropologists go to study people in other countries and cities, digital anthropologists study public sites and groups on the Internet: they keep diaries of observations, talk to users on the sly, and learn the social meaning of various rituals and concepts.
In this project, you can be a researcher and / or a reader or viewer.
Disclaimers:
The project is based on replicas found on the Internet about a difficult ambiguous experience. They can be unpleasant or provocative for some viewers.

spekts.length: Act 1 — 1 hour 10 minutes, Act 2 — 1 hour 20 minutes.

children: Project of the Internet and Society Lovers Club

1. The performance consists of two parts. The first part is the collection and discussion of online materials. Participants meet on the Zoom platform and go to various Internet resources to collect materials for the cheats. The second is an offline reading of the texts collected in the first part.

2. You can participate in both parts or only one of them. Participation in the online part is available for free upon registration, to participate in both parts of the performance, you need to buy a ticket.
3. After registration, all participants and participants of the online part will receive an email with a link to view it.
4. For the online part of the performance, you will need the Zoom app and a laptop.
Directed by
Polina Kolozaridi

The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Chekhov's "The Seagull", played by robots

Non-human agents also have the right to life, culture, and their own worldview. The director of the play-a Robot-Kostya (model Hyundai HS165-02) — gathered a team of other non-biological performers. Together, they analyzed all the directorial experience that they found in the public domain, and began rehearsals, choosing Chekhov's "The Seagull" for their first production.

Using the method of effective analysis and combining it with etude practices, non-human agents analyze the material of Chekhov's play and try to express the difficult problems of the drama of the beginning of the XX century. They are aware that it will be difficult for them on the territory of the traditional Russian theater, but the director of the Robot-Kostya, nevertheless, is sure: new forms are needed.

About their production, the robo-artists say: "We do not hesitate to experiment and, moving along the dramatic outline of the play, sometimes we hear how in the technocratic space of the play, the biological voices of the recording of the production of The Seagull in the middle of the XX century appear as something otherworldly and unknown".
Joint production of Planetarium No. 1 and the Institute of Advanced Technologies

cover.title: My vyidem s soboy v les

children: An audio production for a single person. A conversation about where childhood goes
daylight hours
in the forest all alone
in your pocket a felt-tip pen, your favorite candy and an apple
on your head headphones, headphones — voice
answer out loud
decide quickly
be honest

An audio performance is a walk that you go on alone — for 36 minutes, a child's voice becomes your guide and interlocutor. He offers to be friends, confides in you secrets, shares fears, fools around, talks about his life and sensitively asks about yours. Asks for honest answers and gives tasks, making the performance interactive. The play does not have a specific route — you choose your own path in the forest. When you immerse yourself in the performance, you remember your childhood, reflect on your real self.
Production by the Impresario Theater Company

spekts.persons: Mikhail Meshcheryakov, Andrey Bykov, Anastasia Mishchenko and Egor Tatarenko

children: An immersive journey to a better country

According to opinion polls, a fifth of Russians would like to move abroad for permanent residence. Over the past 3 years, the number of applicants has increased by almost 15% and continues to grow. More than half of them represent the age group from 18 to 24 years. The team of the play explores this phenomenon, based on the political situation in Russia and the world, and also on the experience of famous emigrants of different years and their friends who left.

"Center of Russian emigration" is an office, some in Russia, a great multitude, which are engaged in the Affairs of Russian emigrants: give permission to leave the country, approve or reject requests for the return.

Viewers have to choose how to pass the performance from a person who seeks to "leave Russia," a former Expat, which aims "to return Home". In the best bureaucratic traditions, participants are waiting for countless offices and endless signatures — all to get the coveted permission.
The project of the theater company

spekts.persons: Elina Kulikova, Dima Efremov, Fyodor Kokorev

children: A musical media production based on a text by Derek Jarman

"My garden is a memorial; every round flower bed is a knot of true love, decorated with lavender, immortelle and santolina", Derek Jarman, one of the key directors of experimental cinema, wrote in his diary a few years before his death from AIDS in 1994.

Today's world is unsettling in its vastness. Modern nature is both the melting of glaciers and the migration of birds, space satellites and a new generation of vaccines. Perhaps the only true form of a person's relationship with the global chaos and uncertainty of modernity is tenderness. Tenderness can become one of the most extreme ways of knowing the world, which other rational methods of humanity failed to disenchant. "Modern Nature" is a statement of this position, a reflection on it in the form of performative and visual poetry, a performance-a poem about awe towards everything that is natural, and about love as the only thing that can last forever.

Jarman's text, which formed the basis of the production, is a rare example of sensual, encyclopedic and at the same time political writing about nature. In his diary, he speaks with his usual passion, not only about the art of cinema, but also about his garden, laid out in the suburbs of London. The garden, which, like the life of the author, is more willing to submit to changes in the seasons or weather disasters, rather than to its creator. Jarman has the same feelings for the garden's inhabitants that he has for romantic partners or friends: care, warmth, attraction, and constant fear for their well-being.
Project of the Voznesensky Center
Elina Kulikova
Dima Efremov
Fyodor Kokorev
Kristina Maloletkina

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. An investigation of sensuality in the digital world and in the world of physical bodies
pseudo_mocumentary digital site-specific.
Exciting the nevernever.

The lover is not given any place. However, the vibrations, gestures, and speech spasms that it creates find their own places in space. We invite the viewer to become a loving agent, whose starting point is the practice of remembering the past. The principle of operation — as you say, so it was.

The story begins in a digital environment, sprouting into urban locations. The participant finds himself in a stream of excited correspondence, where quotes from Deleuze and Pressiado are juxtaposed with the songs of the band "Animals", and wordplay and pure concepts develop into dirty talk.

The play focuses on different registers of sensuality, manifestations of romantic and sexual attraction in the digital space and in the world of physical bodies, as well as the attitude of society to such practices. The release of sensuality from the repressed state is considered as one of the desired effects of the performance.
The disclaimer is ironic: during the performance, the audience may experience a strong excitement. Instructions for resolving arousal are under development.
Disclaimer non-ironic: sensitive and explicit topics may be discussed in the performance, please evaluate your strength if they can be a trigger for you.

spekts.length: The experience is unevenly distributed over 5 days and does not require the participant to abandon his daily activities.

spekts.name: Weekends Come but Once a Week

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires. We assembled the programme by feeling our way through and listening to ourselves, choosing projects capable of granting us an experience of a total shift in perspective. Or, more accurately, capable of revealing realities of the most varied nature undetectable at first glance. For instance, the manifestation of women’s invisible labor in the film industry is the subject of the theatrical/artistic laboratory Vokrug da Okolo’s production Movie Ticket, the site of which will logically be Lenfilm Studios, where female co-workers and co-creators (not muses) worked unseen alongside the great masters of the craft. Pyotr Kurkin’s School Simulator will send the audience to a class and recess, allowing them to feel those countless strings that bind classmates together and which forever bind us (whether or not we want to admit it) to our classroom desks and the ring of the school bell.

In the programme of reenactments of famous performances (Vanya Demidkin and Artyom Tomilov’s Unexpectedly Wonderful), acts well-known to us from recent art history resonate in a completely different way with today’s reality. Or maybe not. None of the eight acts will be announced in advance, so as not to anaesthetize the audience’s perception. Ilya Moshitsky’s production Flights will be a journey without borders, a trip into ourselves capable of revealing our unconscious impulses, those hidden under the weight of civilization. The Norwegian director and actionist Morten Traavik’s exhibition project PARTY SONGS will let us peek into the world’s most closed-off country, North Korea. Is it worth mentioning that upon close inspection, even that country isn’t at all what it seems? Festival-goers can look for the protagonists of Ksenia Peretrukhina’s projects in parks: tiny vandals (Bad Little People) and giant elderly people living out their warm, fuzzy lives in ease (Weekends Come but Once a Week). In the project tentatively titled Rosa, Sergei Chekhov and Rosa Khayrullina will call the laws of thermodynamics into question: the actress’s body will come into contact with cosmic energy, casting light on the dark areas of the most precise science (although things might go differently in what is so far the most mysterious project in the festival programme).

Last year’s festival took place entirely online, but the 2021 programme features productions that exist both on the internet and in the real world, opening up different degrees of immersion.  Each project that presupposes physical participation will have a digital double that will eliminate the need to overcome geographic distance. The main programme doesn’t have any headliners; all the projects are a mutual risk. By request of The Access Point, the young directors are doing things they’ve never done before (with the exception of Morten Traavik, but that’s another matter entirely). We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.
The poetry of daily life as performed by puppets
"Weekend..." - a puppet show, the audience of which can be anyone who was in the garden. You just need to stop for a minute and see: what are these elderly heroes doing?

They are busy with their simple tasks: someone is dancing, someone is taking pictures, someone is having a picnic. Old people can afford not to rush anywhere and spend time with pleasure. The only thing they can't do is talk. It's probably difficult for them to talk, or maybe they just don't want to, because it's not necessary to talk for communication.

The project removes the stigma from the topic of old age, makes the invisible visible and works with the practice of non-verbal communication. It helps to feel that speech and intelligence are only a small part of our communication capabilities.
The online version of the project contains real stories of people who became prototypes of the characters of the play.
Instructions for viewers of the online version of the project will appear later.
Production of the Karlsson Haus Theater commissioned by
the Access Point Festival
Project curator:
Ksenia Peretrukhina
Actors of the Karlsson Haus theater:
Philip Borodin, Asya Galimzyanova, Alice Drozdova, Denis Polevikov, Ksenia Ponomareva-Borodina, Maxim Maksimov, Kristina Tsurkan, Renat Shavaliev
The Online Version Team:
Text:
Alina Ismailova
Design and layout:
Ekaterina Farutina

From act to action and back: private and public “doings” in the practices of the Radek Community, 1999-2006
From act to action and back: private and public “doings” in the practices of the Radek Community, 1999-2006.
Pyotr Bystrov

Artist, curator. Co-founder and member of Radek Community, a group of young, radically inclined artists that existed from the mid-1990s until the mid-2000s. Among Radek’s actions was Demonstration (2000), in which the artists unfurled banners on a crosswalk and turned the pedestrian traffic into a protest.

An immersive production that sends the audience back to school
an in-house production of The Access Point Festival

What kind of person should a school produce? Most would say that it’s someone certain of their future, with a fully-formed identity. But what kind of people actually graduate? Often they’re bewildered, lacking the answers to many of their questions and an understanding of what to do next. The knowledge they get in class doesn’t always correspond to real life, and the ideals their education attempts to impart in them can be unattainable in practice.

School Simulator invites you to go back in time and try to work through the problems they haven’t solved since then. As you sit in Literature class, you’ll reevaluate your experience of school and attempt to assess what you actually learned and what mistakes you made. Inside the classroom of the simulation, you’ll only have to find yourself.
An in-house production of
the Access Point Festival

Peter Kurkin

An eyewitness account from a representative of the Russian performance scene after and before the Iron Curtain.
Elena Kovylina

Artist, art critic, curator of Khodynka Gallery and creator of PYRFYR, Moscow’s first performance art school. Elena Kovylina has been creating performance pieces since the 1990s, alienating and pushing to their absurd extreme common practices and rituals, putting herself in danger and thereby studying the possibilities of communication with the audience.

International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
A performative investigation of the interaction between the body and cyberspace

EMBEDDED INTERNET offers a departure from the representation of technology as rational, cold, disembodied, patriarchal, heteronormative. The authors strive to manifest a new corporeality of the Internet space, to create a new web body, taking into account its fluidity, post-gender, digitalization of the skin, new privacy and sensuality.
Disclaimer:
bright light, loud sound.

erformance artist:
Katya Bondar
P
erformance artist:

spekts.name: The Lake You Live in and Walk Around

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
Audio performance dedicated to the folklore and ethnography of the Sami people of Karelia and the Kola Peninsula
To be smaller than you seem, to wander around for a long time and
notice something new every time

The Kola Peninsula and Karelia are places where the soundscape is closely intertwined with folklore. Real locations are associated with those described in Sami fairy tales. For example, the Black Varaka from the legends — a magnet for all evil spirits-rhymes with the deserted and creepy Karelian hill. And the story of the old woman who sits inside the mountain and guards the gold, today becomes an image of the ecological depression of the region: working mines destroy the environment, but bring profit to the industrialists. The authors of the installation discover an ecological subtext in the stories of Sami fairy tales about man and nature.

The audience will travel to the dome of the Museum of the Arctic and Antarctic accompanied by Sami fairy tales in headphones. One of the storylines, where the characters decided to live differently, will lead to a utopian ending — unusual ways of interacting with people and objects, with the fictional and the real.
Disclaimer:

In the space of the museum there is a staircase without a lift, so access to the performance can be difficult for people with limited mobility. In this case, you can stay on the first floor, listen to the audio and watch what is happening.
Sound designer and traveler:
Daniil Koronkevich
Playwright:
Alina Shklarskaya
Produced by
Anna Chekhov

children: A series of installations under your feet
a dynamic performative installation by the Karlsson Haus Theatre commissioned by The Access Point Festival

This project consists of a series of installations united by the characters they share. The little people enter familiar spaces and break down the established order. In one installation, a group of people attempt to chop down a linden tree, while a little person climbs up onto one of its branches and cuts it down from under him. In another, they decide to move a bench. In yet another, they plan to steal something. The characters can be found in the most varied of places — you only have to look around or under your feet to find them.

The project deals with the theme of ecological consciousness, drawing attention to the short-sightedness of people today and their indifference to the environment. Watching the characters, brought to life in the animated aesthetic, becomes an opportunity to talk about ecology, not only among adults, but with children as well.

The project’s online version, integrated into the augmented reality app AR Hunter, will allow you to introduce the little people to any space. Your home, for example, where you can continue the discussion at your leisure.
Dynamic performative installation of the Karlsson Haus Theater commissioned by
the Access Point Festival
Author: Yulia Preobrazhenskaya
Designer: Elizaveta Skorobogatova
Curator: Ksenia Peretrukhina
The AR Hunter app team

spekts.name: The performative conference "Between Procrastination and Accelerationism: Contemporary Poetic Practices in the Age of Precarious Work"

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
A conversation about contemporary poetry and humanitarian theory

The performative conference is designed to comprehend, on the one hand, the turn to edutainment and self — education in modern society, and on the other hand, it offers to look at the conference as a self-sufficient form capable of producing new meanings in the scientific and artistic field.

The conference will bring together contemporary poets, poetesses and poetesses from the circle "Red Knowledge", who will discuss their insecurity and vulnerability in the conditions of increasing precarization of creative work in the field of capitalist labor relations. After all, modern poets are, rather, neurotic, scattered, fluid and fragmented biomachines of writing, from which capitalism requires constant acceleration, and critical reflexive thinking and poetic imagination, on the contrary, slow down.
Disclaimer: A willingness to perceive and discuss current poetry and contemporary humanitarian theory. The desire to be involved in the joint process of writing poetry.
Organizer:
Roman Osminkin
Speakers:
Vlad Gagin, Nikita Sungatov, Sergey Finogin, Elena Fofanova, Ramil Niyazov-Adyldzhan, Yulia Chernysheva, Dmitry Gerchikov
The team of the DK Rozy:
Dmitry Vilensky, Olga Rusakova, Anna Averyanova

The main programme doesn’t have any headliners; all the projects are a mutual risk. By request of The Access Point, the young directors are doing things they’ve never done before (with the exception of Morten Traavik, but that’s another matter entirely). We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.
A journey based on the novel by Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk
an in-house production of The Access Point Festival

A journey based on Flights, a novel by Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk. Flights consists of texts written on the road about the road. These texts were created in a changing century of new technology and acceleration, a time when oceans can be crossed in a matter of hours and airports open portals to other cultures and civilizations.

The production touches upon themes of self-identity and the fear of death while attempting to solve the mysteries we hold in our own bodies. Along with its female protagonist who regards her life as a journey and sees the meaning of her existence in constant motion, the audience immerse themselves in a story that ends up splitting in two. They are given the right to choose to remain spectators following the events online or become participants in an adventure, setting out on a path that will lead them to the central point of the production, where drum rhythms and a warm campfire await.
An in-house production of
the Access Point Festival
Director:
Ilya Moshitsky
Performers:
Alisher Umarov, Ekaterina Kramarenko, Anastasia Balueva

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
A project in which twenty artists under the direction of Gian-Maria Tosatti explore and comprehend the space on the border of two countries: Russia and Estonia.
Curatorts — Yulia Kleiman and Alexey Platunov.

This year, the festival’s main principle — the study of borderline states in art — will be carried out literally. The Border Laboratory will take place at the Russian-Estonian border zone in the cities of Ivangorod and Narva.

The Italian artist and visionary Gian Maria Tosatti will join us in studying broders in both the literal and figurative sense, blurring genres and art forms, overcoming the boundaries between the physical and virtual, and closely inspecting the specifics of the
genius loci
. The
genius
of Ivangorod and Narva is quite specific: once a single city with a common infrastructure and industrial area, it was forever divided artificially by the border that now runs through it.
Страница опен-колла лаборатории

International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
Performance-playbook for one viewer

Everyone leaves countless traces in their path, most of which dissolve with time. We are definitely made up of places that we have once visited: even if it is invisible, virtual, or present there in dreams. The sum of all these places is equal to our experience of space perception, and therefore to our entire view of the world.

|common place| — a performance for a single audience that recreates our own psychogeography. All the events, characters and scenery of the play are placed in a paper book. Its pages contain tactile and tangible paths that the viewer can walk at any time and place convenient for him. Every playbook like this is unique: you can't really know which one you're going to get. Perhaps it will turn out to be an autofiction landscape of Polina's childhood, or a digital landscape of Elina's desktop. The route of the performance may be unexpected, but after all, unpredictability is the most valuable thing in any journey?
Authors:
Polina Cardamon and Elina Kulikova

Complaints about life and other forms of experience — a performance made up of monologues by young women about problems and time
"33 sisters":
we are all sisters to each other in some way

"33 sisters" is a performance based on the thoughts and opinions of the girls, their experiences, problems and arguments about the time in which they live. The main character here is the viewer himself, his assessment, his emotion, his sensuality.

The project came from an experiment. The authors asked those who wanted to reread Chekhov's play and answer one question: "What is happening in it?". The answer of 90% of the participants was: "The heroines can not go to Moscow and whine, complain about something." This conclusion became the starting point of the performance.
The performance was created with the support of the Perm State Medical University named after Academician E. A. Wagner and the Ministry of Tourism and Youth Policy of the Perm Region
Curator:
Sasha Shumilin
Producer:
Maxim Potaskuev
Line producer:
Irina Simakova
Director:
Katya Shumilova

Perfomance-constructor built on the interaction of the audience and the mysterious premise
An empty room, a package from an unknown sender, and a CD player. Documentary basis, no actors and live reflection in real time.

The project was preceded by a series of surveys of ordinary people in Kherson, Bishkek and Cologne. It is with these people, more precisely, with their textual and objective reflection, that the audience will interact. The authors limit the problems of the play to the triangle "pandemic-modern economy-personal happiness", but suggest that the performance can lead the viewer further. Or don't get it anywhere at all. It all depends on the situation that develops during the viewing. Sender unknown is a performance constructor that is created in a new way every time.
Disclaimer:
Items of a sexual nature are used

The performance was created as part of the project "A Package from abroad" with the support of the Goethe Institute (International Coproduction Fund), the Ministry of Culture and Science of the Federal State of North Rhine-Westphalia

A conversational production about the nature of desire/10 rooms, honesty and you

"Northern Lights" is a performance-conversation in which the viewer passes through a series of spaces, interacting with artists and installations, gaining sensory experience and new knowledge about the nature of desire.
The creators of the play combine an ironic tone with serious themes, exploring such issues as attraction, security, taboo, queer theory, asexuality and others.
The performance is created in the site-specific format, fitting into the existing space of the Wynwood Boutique Hotel and transforming it at the expense of theatrical funds.
Disclaimers:
The performance is interactive — there is a direct interaction with the viewer, including tactile. The viewer can stop the interaction at any time and leave the room.
Independent project of Elena Nenasheva and Vika Privalova

International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
An online game investigating tolerance in the post-pandemic world

An immersive online performance where the audience decides who is allowed to live in a post-tandem world. The plot is based on the interrogation of "outsiders" who want to get citizenship in a city that survived the apocalypse. The heroes of the play-game are representatives of different races, nationalities, religions, social groups, sexual orientation and carriers of a variety of experiences. The text is based on documentary material: the questions are taken from real questionnaires of migration services and questionnaires to identify the degree of tolerance among schoolchildren. The play works with the problem of tolerance, offering viewers to evaluate their own tendency to follow prejudices, their willingness to make unbiased judgments about others and to recognize the right of others to live according to their worldview.
Disclaimer:

The performance is not recommended for viewing for people with unstable mentality. Some scenes may contain information about the humiliation of a person or group of persons on the grounds of gender, race, nationality, language, origin, attitude to religion or belonging to a social group.
A joint project of director Anastasia Kireeva and game designer Nikita Altman in the
Live Action Theater

The internet becomes the festival’s space. The Access Point launches a Spontaneous Programme of online productions, inviting everyone interested in investigating communication in the pandemic to present their projects. The Educational Programme features leading artists from Europe, North America and Australia.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires. We assembled the programme by feeling our way through and listening to ourselves, choosing projects capable of granting us an experience of a total shift in perspective. Or, more accurately, capable of revealing realities of the most varied nature undetectable at first glance. For instance, the manifestation of women’s invisible labor in the film industry is the subject of the theatrical/artistic laboratory Vokrug da Okolo’s production Movie Ticket, the site of which will logically be Lenfilm Studios, where female co-workers and co-creators (not muses) worked unseen alongside the great masters of the craft. Pyotr Kurkin’s School Simulator will send the audience to a class and recess, allowing them to feel those countless strings that bind classmates together and which forever bind us (whether or not we want to admit it) to our classroom desks and the ring of the school bell.

In the programme of reenactments of famous performances (Vanya Demidkin and Artyom Tomilov’s Unexpectedly Wonderful), acts well-known to us from recent art history resonate in a completely different way with today’s reality. Or maybe not. None of the eight acts will be announced in advance, so as not to anaesthetize the audience’s perception. Ilya Moshitsky’s production Flights will be a journey without borders, a trip into ourselves capable of revealing our unconscious impulses, those hidden under the weight of civilization. The Norwegian director and actionist Morten Traavik’s exhibition project PARTY SONGS will let us peek into the world’s most closed-off country, North Korea. Is it worth mentioning that upon close inspection, even that country isn’t at all what it seems? Festival-goers can look for the protagonists of Ksenia Peretrukhina’s projects in parks: tiny vandals (Bad Little People) and giant elderly people living out their warm, fuzzy lives in ease (Weekends Come but Once a Week). In the project tentatively titled Rosa, Sergei Chekhov and Rosa Khayrullina will call the laws of thermodynamics into question: the actress’s body will come into contact with cosmic energy, casting light on the dark areas of the most precise science (although things might go differently in what is so far the most mysterious project in the festival programme).

Last year’s festival took place entirely online, but the 2021 programme features productions that exist both on the internet and in the real world, opening up different degrees of immersion.  Each project that presupposes physical participation will have a digital double that will eliminate the need to overcome geographic distance. The main programme doesn’t have any headliners; all the projects are a mutual risk. By request of The Access Point, the young directors are doing things they’ve never done before (with the exception of Morten Traavik, but that’s another matter entirely). We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.

children: “Play in a Box” is not really a play. Sometimes it becomes a poetic essay gravitating towards documentary and anthropology.

“Play in a Box” is not really a play. Sometimes it becomes a poetic essay gravitating towards documentary and anthropology. And sometimes it looks more like a playful radio play from an old record. The performance is assembled into chapters, scattered across the site page, like beads. The audience listens to them one by one, stringing the plot on a thread. So the site turns into a map of actions, and the performance - into a path. The production is available for viewing in two modes: free, where viewers can go through or even assemble it on their own at any time convenient for them, or in a show mode with author's accompaniment.

The performance takes the audience to Venice, where the bulk of the sound material was collected *. The authors tried to consider the phenomenon of Venice as an exhibit city or an attraction city, constantly existing both under the gaze of many tourists, and (economically) due to this gaze. Venice is a city that has to endlessly enchant and exoticize itself, keep the mark of antiquity and uniqueness.

The enchanted Venice is hallucinating about itself, and in this we can see its relationship with St. Petersburg. The artists ask themselves what the socio-political dimension of the enchanted city could be? They look for answers to it, talking with the Venetians, and when the questions lose their meaning, they begin to make riddles. Continuing to reflect on this topic, the team turns to Red Gothic. This is a phenomenon in Soviet literature of the twenties, containing a dimension of magic and mysticism emerging from the dark corners of the unconscious.

It was very important for the “Around the Bush” team to find a place within the performance for the usually repressed aspects of production: the authors' lack of synchronicity of thinking, translation problems, misunderstanding and confusion, feelings of awkwardness and shame of the researcher arising during work. All this adds up to a non-linear and sensual "Performance in a Box", shimmering in different genres and forms, which, instead of fighting for the championship, are struggling to come to an agreement.

* The premiere of the audio performance took place in November 2019 in the space of the V-A-C Palazzo Zattere Foundation in Venice, and in the festival program it will exist in a specially created online version.
Свободный режим

Зрители могут самостоятельно распаковать «Спектакль в коробочке», пройдя по одной или нескольким тропам. Каждая из троп представляет собой вариант монтажной сборки спектакля: полной авторской или более короткой тематической.
Сайт находится в открытом доступе с 16 июня по 24 июля. Все необходимые инструкции вы найдете на сайте.
Показ с авторским сопровождением

Зрители смогут пройти по авторской тропе вместе с участницами коллектива «Вокруг да около», а после спектакля обсудить увиденное и услышанное с создательницами спектакля и между собой. The internet becomes the festival’s space. The Access Point launches a Spontaneous Programme of online productions, inviting everyone interested in investigating communication in the pandemic to present their projects. The Educational Programme features leading artists from Europe, North America and Australia.

The festival features two concurrent tracks: the curated projects that form its Main Programme, and its Free Programme of almost 30 fringe productions, performances and installations. The large-scale Educational Programme now consists of more than public lectures — it also includes a series of closed, hands-on group classes with leading theatre instructors from Italy, Denmark and USA. The results of these classes are workshop productions made by those in attendance.

The internet becomes the festival’s space. The Access Point launches a Spontaneous Programme of online productions, inviting everyone interested in investigating communication in the pandemic to present their projects. The Educational Programme features leading artists from Europe, North America and Australia.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires. We assembled the programme by feeling our way through and listening to ourselves, choosing projects capable of granting us an experience of a total shift in perspective. Or, more accurately, capable of revealing realities of the most varied nature undetectable at first glance. For instance, the manifestation of women’s invisible labor in the film industry is the subject of the theatrical/artistic laboratory Vokrug da Okolo’s production Movie Ticket, the site of which will logically be Lenfilm Studios, where female co-workers and co-creators (not muses) worked unseen alongside the great masters of the craft. Pyotr Kurkin’s School Simulator will send the audience to a class and recess, allowing them to feel those countless strings that bind classmates together and which forever bind us (whether or not we want to admit it) to our classroom desks and the ring of the school bell.

In the programme of reenactments of famous performances (Vanya Demidkin and Artyom Tomilov’s Unexpectedly Wonderful), acts well-known to us from recent art history resonate in a completely different way with today’s reality. Or maybe not. None of the eight acts will be announced in advance, so as not to anaesthetize the audience’s perception. Ilya Moshitsky’s production Flights will be a journey without borders, a trip into ourselves capable of revealing our unconscious impulses, those hidden under the weight of civilization. The Norwegian director and actionist Morten Traavik’s exhibition project PARTY SONGS will let us peek into the world’s most closed-off country, North Korea. Is it worth mentioning that upon close inspection, even that country isn’t at all what it seems? Festival-goers can look for the protagonists of Ksenia Peretrukhina’s projects in parks: tiny vandals (Bad Little People) and giant elderly people living out their warm, fuzzy lives in ease (Weekends Come but Once a Week). In the project tentatively titled Rosa, Sergei Chekhov and Rosa Khayrullina will call the laws of thermodynamics into question: the actress’s body will come into contact with cosmic energy, casting light on the dark areas of the most precise science (although things might go differently in what is so far the most mysterious project in the festival programme).

Last year’s festival took place entirely online, but the 2021 programme features productions that exist both on the internet and in the real world, opening up different degrees of immersion.  Each project that presupposes physical participation will have a digital double that will eliminate the need to overcome geographic distance. The main programme doesn’t have any headliners; all the projects are a mutual risk. By request of The Access Point, the young directors are doing things they’ve never done before (with the exception of Morten Traavik, but that’s another matter entirely). We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.

sponsors.name: a dynamic performative installation by the Karlsson Haus Theatre commissioned by The Access Point Festival

homepages.shortDesc: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.

main.name: Inexplicably Wonderful. Performances of the past today

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires. We assembled the programme by feeling our way through and listening to ourselves, choosing projects capable of granting us an experience of a total shift in perspective. Or, more accurately, capable of revealing realities of the most varied nature undetectable at first glance. For instance, the manifestation of women’s invisible labor in the film industry is the subject of the theatrical/artistic laboratory Vokrug da Okolo’s production Movie Ticket, the site of which will logically be Lenfilm Studios, where female co-workers and co-creators (not muses) worked unseen alongside the great masters of the craft. Pyotr Kurkin’s School Simulator will send the audience to a class and recess, allowing them to feel those countless strings that bind classmates together and which forever bind us (whether or not we want to admit it) to our classroom desks and the ring of the school bell.

In the programme of reenactments of famous performances (Vanya Demidkin and Artyom Tomilov’s Unexpectedly Wonderful), acts well-known to us from recent art history resonate in a completely different way with today’s reality. Or maybe not. None of the eight acts will be announced in advance, so as not to anaesthetize the audience’s perception. Ilya Moshitsky’s production Flights will be a journey without borders, a trip into ourselves capable of revealing our unconscious impulses, those hidden under the weight of civilization. The Norwegian director and actionist Morten Traavik’s exhibition project PARTY SONGS will let us peek into the world’s most closed-off country, North Korea. Is it worth mentioning that upon close inspection, even that country isn’t at all what it seems? Festival-goers can look for the protagonists of Ksenia Peretrukhina’s projects in parks: tiny vandals (Bad Little People) and giant elderly people living out their warm, fuzzy lives in ease (Weekends Come but Once a Week). In the project tentatively titled Rosa, Sergei Chekhov and Rosa Khayrullina will call the laws of thermodynamics into question: the actress’s body will come into contact with cosmic energy, casting light on the dark areas of the most precise science (although things might go differently in what is so far the most mysterious project in the festival programme).

Last year’s festival took place entirely online, but the 2021 programme features productions that exist both on the internet and in the real world, opening up different degrees of immersion.  Each project that presupposes physical participation will have a digital double that will eliminate the need to overcome geographic distance. The main programme doesn’t have any headliners; all the projects are a mutual risk. By request of The Access Point, the young directors are doing things they’ve never done before (with the exception of Morten Traavik, but that’s another matter entirely). We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.
A series of performances from the past, reconstructed and adapted to the present

The history of performance art cannot be seen as a single, objective and finished narrative; art is described by people from a specific era, which means those descriptions are replete with the stereotypes and prejudices of their time. How, then, are we to study the history of performance art today? What does it still contain, and what has it lost? Can we make our own history of it? And, if so, how?

Inexplicably Wonderful is a series of performances from the past, reconstructed and adapted to the present context and state of culture. In art theory, this sort of reconstruction is often called a reenactment. That term appeared at the turn of the 21st century to describe the phenomenon in which historical events and art projects are recreated.
We work with stories from the past: famous and forgotten, important and incidental, obvious and accidental. Still, the programme we’ve put together is not the history of performance art
per se

, but an affirmation of the impossibility to grasp it fully. Each of the eight works reflects the vectors that performance art has been moving through over time. You will see Soviet performances and the historic avant-garde, conceptualism and feminist art, the principles of randomness and urban intervention.
An in-house production of
the Access Point Festival
Curators and Directors:
Vanya Demidkin and Artyom Tomilov

The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
Off/On.

We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.
The poetry of daily life as performed by puppets
"Weekend..." - a puppet show, the audience of which can be anyone who was in the garden. You just need to stop for a minute and see: what are these elderly heroes doing?

They are busy with their simple tasks: someone is dancing, someone is taking pictures, someone is having a picnic. Old people can afford not to rush anywhere and spend time with pleasure. The only thing they can't do is talk. It's probably difficult for them to talk, or maybe they just don't want to, because it's not necessary to talk for communication.

The project removes the stigma from the topic of old age, makes the invisible visible and works with the practice of non-verbal communication. It helps to feel that speech and intelligence are only a small part of our communication capabilities.
The online version of the project contains real stories of people who became prototypes of the characters of the play.
Instructions for viewers of the online version of the project will appear later.
Production of the Karlsson Haus Theater commissioned by
the Access Point Festival
Project curator:
Ksenia Peretrukhina
Actors of the Karlsson Haus theater:
Philip Borodin, Asya Galimzyanova, Alice Drozdova, Denis Polevikov, Ksenia Ponomareva-Borodina, Maxim Maksimov, Kristina Tsurkan, Renat Shavaliev
The Online Version Team:
Text:
Alina Ismailova
Design and layout:
Ekaterina Farutina

A journey based on the novel by Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk
an in-house production of The Access Point Festival

A journey based on Flights, a novel by Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk. Flights consists of texts written on the road about the road. These texts were created in a changing century of new technology and acceleration, a time when oceans can be crossed in a matter of hours and airports open portals to other cultures and civilizations.

The production touches upon themes of self-identity and the fear of death while attempting to solve the mysteries we hold in our own bodies. Along with its female protagonist who regards her life as a journey and sees the meaning of her existence in constant motion, the audience immerse themselves in a story that ends up splitting in two. They are given the right to choose to remain spectators following the events online or become participants in an adventure, setting out on a path that will lead them to the central point of the production, where drum rhythms and a warm campfire await.
An in-house production of
the Access Point Festival
Director:
Ilya Moshitsky
Performers:
Alisher Umarov, Ekaterina Kramarenko, Anastasia Balueva

A documentary project about North Korea
a multi-genre project by Morten Traavik (Norway)

Morten Traavik is a Norwegian director and creator of theatre productions, exhibitions, films and activist art projects. Travik learned his theatre craft in Sweden and Russia. For over ten years, Traavik’s main source of inspiration has been North Korea. It was he who took a delegation of radical European artists and the Slovenian avant-garde music group Laibach to North Korea, organizing the country’s first rock concert and making a documentary film about it.

During the festival, Traavik will present the documentary, an exhibition and two books: The Traitor’s Guide to North Korea, a book hotly recommended by booksellers everywhere, and Liberation Days: Laibach and North Korea. The exhibition will feature photographs and audio and video recordings of various aspects of existence in North Korea today, both through the prism of government propaganda and everyday life, juxtaposed with examples of mass adoration of western and Russian pop stars.
The project is investigating the possibilities of pop music as an instrument of control and liberation that brings together idolatry, hero-worship and still darker strains of mass behavior.
Multi-genre project by Morten Traavik (Norway)
Artistic director, director, writer:
Morten Traavik
Photographers:
Jørund F. Pedersen, Simoulin Jean-Emmanuel Marie
Photographer and graphic designer:
Valnoir
Producer:
Lyuba Kuzovnikova
Coordinator:
Katya Pirogova

Or maybe not. None of the eight acts will be announced in advance, so as not to anaesthetize the audience’s perception. Ilya Moshitsky’s production Flights will be a journey without borders, a trip into ourselves capable of revealing our unconscious impulses, those hidden under the weight of civilization. The Norwegian director and actionist Morten Traavik’s exhibition project PARTY SONGS will let us peek into the world’s most closed-off country, North Korea. Is it worth mentioning that upon close inspection, even that country isn’t at all what it seems? Festival-goers can look for the protagonists of Ksenia Peretrukhina’s projects in parks: tiny vandals (Bad Little People) and giant elderly people living out their warm, fuzzy lives in ease (Weekends Come but Once a Week). In the project tentatively titled Rosa, Sergei Chekhov and Rosa Khayrullina will call the laws of thermodynamics into question: the actress’s body will come into contact with cosmic energy, casting light on the dark areas of the most precise science (although things might go differently in what is so far the most mysterious project in the festival programme).

Last year’s festival took place entirely online, but the 2021 programme features productions that exist both on the internet and in the real world, opening up different degrees of immersion.  Each project that presupposes physical participation will have a digital double that will eliminate the need to overcome geographic distance. The main programme doesn’t have any headliners; all the projects are a mutual risk. By request of The Access Point, the young directors are doing things they’ve never done before (with the exception of Morten Traavik, but that’s another matter entirely). We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.
A documentary journey based on the forgotten women of Lenfilm
an in-house production of The Access Point Festival in partnership with Lenfilm Studios

A movie ticket is a sort of contract between the audience entering the movie theatre and all the people who participated in the film’s production and distribution. We agree to spend our time there and look at the screen, existing in the temporality proposed by the film. To a certain degree, that also means we agree to see what we’re shown, making our gaze match the camera lens and, as a result, turning a blind eye to everything happening outside of the frame.

But here, the movie ticket is also a journey deep into the filmmaking process. We break out of the standard viewing situation by entering the film studio through the screen. In so doing, we demystify the “magic of cinema,” defy the iron grip of the director-demiurge and permit the audience’s gaze not to merge with the camera lens but instead to see the complex network of interactions between the many agents of film production, so often nameless and unseen. We attempt to find a different magic of cinema: the “magic of the invisible,” of the fragile, semi-transparent layers of superimposed film that
together

create a moving picture. We trace a new horizon for magical, humorous and strange cinema — small-scale, personal, mysterious and local. We’ll be searching the halls of Lenfilm for traces of cinematic sorceresses, rewriting history as
her
story.

These invisible agents are fragile. Their names can be easily taken from them and they’re just as easily forgotten. They’re used to being referred to as “so-and-so’s wife.” But they’re also very dangerous. Until they’re spotted, they engage in secret, serious work, eating away at the palace from the inside. And one day it will be impossible not to see or hear them.
An in-house production of
the Access Point festival
in partnership with the
Lenfilm Studios
The theatrical/artistic laboratory Vokrug da Okolo:
Leila Alieva
Daria Bresler
Vlada Milovskaya
Jenya L Zban

Evgeny Kuiru                                                                                                                         Artem Stepanov                                                                                                                                                Andrey Muzhdaba

children: A series of installations under your feet
a dynamic performative installation by the Karlsson Haus Theatre commissioned by The Access Point Festival

This project consists of a series of installations united by the characters they share. The little people enter familiar spaces and break down the established order. In one installation, a group of people attempt to chop down a linden tree, while a little person climbs up onto one of its branches and cuts it down from under him. In another, they decide to move a bench. In yet another, they plan to steal something. The characters can be found in the most varied of places — you only have to look around or under your feet to find them.

The project deals with the theme of ecological consciousness, drawing attention to the short-sightedness of people today and their indifference to the environment. Watching the characters, brought to life in the animated aesthetic, becomes an opportunity to talk about ecology, not only among adults, but with children as well.

The project’s online version, integrated into the augmented reality app AR Hunter, will allow you to introduce the little people to any space. Your home, for example, where you can continue the discussion at your leisure.
Dynamic performative installation of the Karlsson Haus Theater commissioned by
the Access Point Festival
Author: Yulia Preobrazhenskaya
Designer: Elizaveta Skorobogatova
Curator: Ksenia Peretrukhina
The AR Hunter app team

children: Deconstructing an actress' media body in real time

We do not yet have the opportunity to get into a space ship, get to the sun, or another celestial body, and study all its properties. All we have is light, radiated, reflected, and twisted. And this light, or what remains of it when it reaches us, is enough to judge a whole range of properties of an object.

And here is Rosa Khairullina with a request to understand what she is; and not just to stop being a Russian artist, but to disincarnate, to stop being a person, to become an object of the so-called inanimate nature, a stone, an installation. Turn into an object of observation, or even contemplation. And it turns out that for every external observer, it is a collection of information that the Internet emits at the request of "Rosa Khairullina". This information becomes the symbolic body of the Rose, and the main material for the Benefit of Rosa Khairullina.

Before the final shows on the new stage of the Alexandrinsky Theater, Rosa will spend 6 days of open work with fragments of her own roles, her symbolic body, renouncing the image that is not really her. This series of performances will eventually provide the material for what will happen on stage during the screenings themselves — what is commonly called a performance.

An immersive production that sends the audience back to school
an in-house production of The Access Point Festival

What kind of person should a school produce? Most would say that it’s someone certain of their future, with a fully-formed identity. But what kind of people actually graduate? Often they’re bewildered, lacking the answers to many of their questions and an understanding of what to do next. The knowledge they get in class doesn’t always correspond to real life, and the ideals their education attempts to impart in them can be unattainable in practice.

School Simulator invites you to go back in time and try to work through the problems they haven’t solved since then. As you sit in Literature class, you’ll reevaluate your experience of school and attempt to assess what you actually learned and what mistakes you made. Inside the classroom of the simulation, you’ll only have to find yourself.
An in-house production of
the Access Point Festival

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
An online game investigating tolerance in the post-pandemic world

An immersive online performance where the audience decides who is allowed to live in a post-tandem world. The plot is based on the interrogation of "outsiders" who want to get citizenship in a city that survived the apocalypse. The heroes of the play-game are representatives of different races, nationalities, religions, social groups, sexual orientation and carriers of a variety of experiences. The text is based on documentary material: the questions are taken from real questionnaires of migration services and questionnaires to identify the degree of tolerance among schoolchildren. The play works with the problem of tolerance, offering viewers to evaluate their own tendency to follow prejudices, their willingness to make unbiased judgments about others and to recognize the right of others to live according to their worldview.
Disclaimer:

The performance is not recommended for viewing for people with unstable mentality. Some scenes may contain information about the humiliation of a person or group of persons on the grounds of gender, race, nationality, language, origin, attitude to religion or belonging to a social group.
A joint project of director Anastasia Kireeva and game designer Nikita Altman in the
Live Action Theater

International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
Performance-playbook for one viewer

Everyone leaves countless traces in their path, most of which dissolve with time. We are definitely made up of places that we have once visited: even if it is invisible, virtual, or present there in dreams. The sum of all these places is equal to our experience of space perception, and therefore to our entire view of the world.

|common place| — a performance for a single audience that recreates our own psychogeography. All the events, characters and scenery of the play are placed in a paper book. Its pages contain tactile and tangible paths that the viewer can walk at any time and place convenient for him. Every playbook like this is unique: you can't really know which one you're going to get. Perhaps it will turn out to be an autofiction landscape of Polina's childhood, or a digital landscape of Elina's desktop. The route of the performance may be unexpected, but after all, unpredictability is the most valuable thing in any journey?
Authors:
Polina Cardamon and Elina Kulikova

open.name: The performative conference "Between Procrastination and Accelerationism: Contemporary Poetic Practices in the Age of Precarious Work"

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
A conversation about contemporary poetry and humanitarian theory

The performative conference is designed to comprehend, on the one hand, the turn to edutainment and self — education in modern society, and on the other hand, it offers to look at the conference as a self-sufficient form capable of producing new meanings in the scientific and artistic field.

The conference will bring together contemporary poets, poetesses and poetesses from the circle "Red Knowledge", who will discuss their insecurity and vulnerability in the conditions of increasing precarization of creative work in the field of capitalist labor relations. After all, modern poets are, rather, neurotic, scattered, fluid and fragmented biomachines of writing, from which capitalism requires constant acceleration, and critical reflexive thinking and poetic imagination, on the contrary, slow down.
Disclaimer: A willingness to perceive and discuss current poetry and contemporary humanitarian theory. The desire to be involved in the joint process of writing poetry.
Organizer:
Roman Osminkin
Speakers:
Vlad Gagin, Nikita Sungatov, Sergey Finogin, Elena Fofanova, Ramil Niyazov-Adyldzhan, Yulia Chernysheva, Dmitry Gerchikov
The team of the DK Rozy:
Dmitry Vilensky, Olga Rusakova, Anna Averyanova

An investigation of sensuality in the digital world and in the world of physical bodies
pseudo_mocumentary digital site-specific.
Exciting the nevernever.

The lover is not given any place. However, the vibrations, gestures, and speech spasms that it creates find their own places in space. We invite the viewer to become a loving agent, whose starting point is the practice of remembering the past. The principle of operation — as you say, so it was.

The story begins in a digital environment, sprouting into urban locations. The participant finds himself in a stream of excited correspondence, where quotes from Deleuze and Pressiado are juxtaposed with the songs of the band "Animals", and wordplay and pure concepts develop into dirty talk.

The play focuses on different registers of sensuality, manifestations of romantic and sexual attraction in the digital space and in the world of physical bodies, as well as the attitude of society to such practices. The release of sensuality from the repressed state is considered as one of the desired effects of the performance.
The disclaimer is ironic: during the performance, the audience may experience a strong excitement. Instructions for resolving arousal are under development.
Disclaimer non-ironic: sensitive and explicit topics may be discussed in the performance, please evaluate your strength if they can be a trigger for you.

open.length: The experience is unevenly distributed over 5 days and does not require the participant to abandon his daily activities.

Perfomance-constructor built on the interaction of the audience and the mysterious premise
An empty room, a package from an unknown sender, and a CD player. Documentary basis, no actors and live reflection in real time.

The project was preceded by a series of surveys of ordinary people in Kherson, Bishkek and Cologne. It is with these people, more precisely, with their textual and objective reflection, that the audience will interact. The authors limit the problems of the play to the triangle "pandemic-modern economy-personal happiness", but suggest that the performance can lead the viewer further. Or don't get it anywhere at all. It all depends on the situation that develops during the viewing. Sender unknown is a performance constructor that is created in a new way every time.
Disclaimer:
Items of a sexual nature are used

A conversational production about the nature of desire/10 rooms, honesty and you

"Northern Lights" is a performance-conversation in which the viewer passes through a series of spaces, interacting with artists and installations, gaining sensory experience and new knowledge about the nature of desire.
The creators of the play combine an ironic tone with serious themes, exploring such issues as attraction, security, taboo, queer theory, asexuality and others.
The performance is created in the site-specific format, fitting into the existing space of the Wynwood Boutique Hotel and transforming it at the expense of theatrical funds.

The performance is interactive — there is a direct interaction with the viewer, including tactile. The viewer can stop the interaction at any time and leave the room.
