open.persons: Mikhail Meshcheryakov, Andrey Bykov, Anastasia Mishchenko and Egor Tatarenko

children: An immersive journey to a better country

According to opinion polls, a fifth of Russians would like to move abroad for permanent residence. Over the past 3 years, the number of applicants has increased by almost 15% and continues to grow. More than half of them represent the age group from 18 to 24 years. The team of the play explores this phenomenon, based on the political situation in Russia and the world, and also on the experience of famous emigrants of different years and their friends who left.

"Center of Russian emigration" is an office, some in Russia, a great multitude, which are engaged in the Affairs of Russian emigrants: give permission to leave the country, approve or reject requests for the return.

Viewers have to choose how to pass the performance from a person who seeks to "leave Russia," a former Expat, which aims "to return Home". In the best bureaucratic traditions, participants are waiting for countless offices and endless signatures — all to get the coveted permission.

Complaints about life and other forms of experience — a performance made up of monologues by young women about problems and time
"33 sisters":
we are all sisters to each other in some way

"33 sisters" is a performance based on the thoughts and opinions of the girls, their experiences, problems and arguments about the time in which they live. The main character here is the viewer himself, his assessment, his emotion, his sensuality.

The project came from an experiment. The authors asked those who wanted to reread Chekhov's play and answer one question: "What is happening in it?". The answer of 90% of the participants was: "The heroines can not go to Moscow and whine, complain about something." This conclusion became the starting point of the performance.
The performance was created with the support of the Perm State Medical University named after Academician E. A. Wagner and the Ministry of Tourism and Youth Policy of the Perm Region

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. Audio performance dedicated to the folklore and ethnography of the Sami people of Karelia and the Kola Peninsula
To be smaller than you seem, to wander around for a long time and
notice something new every time

The Kola Peninsula and Karelia are places where the soundscape is closely intertwined with folklore. Real locations are associated with those described in Sami fairy tales. For example, the Black Varaka from the legends — a magnet for all evil spirits-rhymes with the deserted and creepy Karelian hill. And the story of the old woman who sits inside the mountain and guards the gold, today becomes an image of the ecological depression of the region: working mines destroy the environment, but bring profit to the industrialists. The authors of the installation discover an ecological subtext in the stories of Sami fairy tales about man and nature.

The audience will travel to the dome of the Museum of the Arctic and Antarctic accompanied by Sami fairy tales in headphones. One of the storylines, where the characters decided to live differently, will lead to a utopian ending — unusual ways of interacting with people and objects, with the fictional and the real.
Disclaimer:

In the space of the museum there is a staircase without a lift, so access to the performance can be difficult for people with limited mobility. In this case, you can stay on the first floor, listen to the audio and watch what is happening.

Chekhov's "The Seagull", played by robots

Non-human agents also have the right to life, culture, and their own worldview. The director of the play-a Robot-Kostya (model Hyundai HS165-02) — gathered a team of other non-biological performers. Together, they analyzed all the directorial experience that they found in the public domain, and began rehearsals, choosing Chekhov's "The Seagull" for their first production.

Using the method of effective analysis and combining it with etude practices, non-human agents analyze the material of Chekhov's play and try to express the difficult problems of the drama of the beginning of the XX century. They are aware that it will be difficult for them on the territory of the traditional Russian theater, but the director of the Robot-Kostya, nevertheless, is sure: new forms are needed.

About their production, the robo-artists say: "We do not hesitate to experiment and, moving along the dramatic outline of the play, sometimes we hear how in the technocratic space of the play, the biological voices of the recording of the production of The Seagull in the middle of the XX century appear as something otherworldly and unknown".
Joint production of Planetarium No. 1 and the Institute of Advanced Technologies

open.persons: Elina Kulikova, Dima Efremov, Fyodor Kokorev

children: A musical media production based on a text by Derek Jarman

"My garden is a memorial; every round flower bed is a knot of true love, decorated with lavender, immortelle and santolina", Derek Jarman, one of the key directors of experimental cinema, wrote in his diary a few years before his death from AIDS in 1994.

Today's world is unsettling in its vastness. Modern nature is both the melting of glaciers and the migration of birds, space satellites and a new generation of vaccines. Perhaps the only true form of a person's relationship with the global chaos and uncertainty of modernity is tenderness. Tenderness can become one of the most extreme ways of knowing the world, which other rational methods of humanity failed to disenchant. "Modern Nature" is a statement of this position, a reflection on it in the form of performative and visual poetry, a performance-a poem about awe towards everything that is natural, and about love as the only thing that can last forever.

Jarman's text, which formed the basis of the production, is a rare example of sensual, encyclopedic and at the same time political writing about nature. In his diary, he speaks with his usual passion, not only about the art of cinema, but also about his garden, laid out in the suburbs of London. The garden, which, like the life of the author, is more willing to submit to changes in the seasons or weather disasters, rather than to its creator. Jarman has the same feelings for the garden's inhabitants that he has for romantic partners or friends: care, warmth, attraction, and constant fear for their well-being.
Project of the Voznesensky Center
Elina Kulikova
Dima Efremov
Fyodor Kokorev
Kristina Maloletkina

cover.title: My vyidem s soboy v les

children: An audio production for a single person. A conversation about where childhood goes
daylight hours
in the forest all alone
in your pocket a felt-tip pen, your favorite candy and an apple
on your head headphones, headphones — voice
answer out loud
decide quickly
be honest

An audio performance is a walk that you go on alone — for 36 minutes, a child's voice becomes your guide and interlocutor. He offers to be friends, confides in you secrets, shares fears, fools around, talks about his life and sensitively asks about yours. Asks for honest answers and gives tasks, making the performance interactive. The play does not have a specific route — you choose your own path in the forest. When you immerse yourself in the performance, you remember your childhood, reflect on your real self.
Production by the Impresario Theater Company

A performative investigation of the interaction between the body and cyberspace

EMBEDDED INTERNET offers a departure from the representation of technology as rational, cold, disembodied, patriarchal, heteronormative. The authors strive to manifest a new corporeality of the Internet space, to create a new web body, taking into account its fluidity, post-gender, digitalization of the skin, new privacy and sensuality.

children: International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. An interactive production based on work with Big Data

The play is about how the Internet turns out to be a place, a way of producing and recognizing statements about complex experiences. What can't be contained or endured, from violence to boredom, becomes written and partly public. The Internet as a space and tool allows such statements to take place and become weighty, meaningful, and effective.
Working with various online materials, studying publications in social networks, participants and participants will be able to form a text for reading under the guidance of moderators.

You will be engaged in digital ethnography. Just as anthropologists go to study people in other countries and cities, digital anthropologists study public sites and groups on the Internet: they keep diaries of observations, talk to users on the sly, and learn the social meaning of various rituals and concepts.
In this project, you can be a researcher and / or a reader or viewer.
Disclaimers:
The project is based on replicas found on the Internet about a difficult ambiguous experience. They can be unpleasant or provocative for some viewers.

open.length: Act 1 — 1 hour 10 minutes, Act 2 — 1 hour 20 minutes.

children: Project of the Internet and Society Lovers Club

1. The performance consists of two parts. The first part is the collection and discussion of online materials. Participants meet on the Zoom platform and go to various Internet resources to collect materials for the cheats. The second is an offline reading of the texts collected in the first part.

2. You can participate in both parts or only one of them. Participation in the online part is available for free upon registration, to participate in both parts of the performance, you need to buy a ticket.
3. After registration, all participants and participants of the online part will receive an email with a link to view it.
4. For the online part of the performance, you will need the Zoom app and a laptop.
Directed by
Polina Kolozaridi

Dmitry Muravyov, Anya Shchetvina, Lenya Yuldashev

An eyewitness account from a representative of the Russian performance scene after and before the Iron Curtain.
Elena Kovylina

Artist, art critic, curator of Khodynka Gallery and creator of PYRFYR, Moscow’s first performance art school. Elena Kovylina has been creating performance pieces since the 1990s, alienating and pushing to their absurd extreme common practices and rituals, putting herself in danger and thereby studying the possibilities of communication with the audience.

From act to action and back: private and public “doings” in the practices of the Radek Community, 1999-2006
From act to action and back: private and public “doings” in the practices of the Radek Community, 1999-2006.
Pyotr Bystrov

Artist, curator. Co-founder and member of Radek Community, a group of young, radically inclined artists that existed from the mid-1990s until the mid-2000s. Among Radek’s actions was Demonstration (2000), in which the artists unfurled banners on a crosswalk and turned the pedestrian traffic into a protest.

Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
Liza Morozova

Artist, researcher, art therapist, columnist. Liza Morozova’s installations and performances have on many occasions participated in major showcases of contemporary art. Her research interests lie in studying the sociopsychological aspects of avant-garde art.

International Summer Festival of Arts "The Access Point" is the largest platform for site-specific and immersive art in Russia. It has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point explores new theatre territories and offers its visitors new experiences in perception and communication with space. Residents and guests of the The Access Point Festival — Russian and international directors — present progressive, bold and pertinent productions. Some of the locations of the previous performances were the following: a commercial centre, a high-profile hotel, The State Russian Museum, a deserted community centre, a garage and a seaport factory, a supermarket and a phone shop. Performances have taken place in the streets and inside private apartments also. In a year 2020 when the only available location for most people around the world was their own homes, the Internet became the festival's theatre space.
Hermann Nitsch

Artist and the most famous figure in Viennese Actionism of the 1960s and 70s. Creator of the Orgien Mysterien Theater, where he performed over 130 actions that are radical even by the standards of the post-war avant-garde. The key themes in his work are victimhood, death and rebirth, and they are always expressed in an extremely naturalistic form.

Lev Manovich

Theorist of new media and digital culture, professor of Computer Science at the City University of New York, instructor at the Strelka Institute for Media, Architecture and Design. Founder of the Cultural Analytics Lab, which works with Google and MoMA. In his books and articles, Manovich reflects on new media in the context of the history of art, film and mass media, and he analyzes changes in our daily strategies and modes of perception in the digital world.

aboutPages.desc: The Access Point International Summer Festival of Arts is the largest forum of site-specific and immersive art in Russia; it has been held in St. Petersburg since 2015. The Access Point is always exploring new territories of the theater and offers the viewer a new experience of perception and communication with the space. Residents and guests of «Access Point» - Russian and foreign directors - explore locations that usually have nothing to do with the theater, and at the same time acquaint viewers with progressive, bold and contemporary art.

Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires.
Off/On.

It seems that over the past year the first option has disappeared, and we’re now in a state of constant engagement (something the Neo-Marxists predicted long ago). Being in a state of engagement and availability 24/7 makes us insensitive to the outside world and ignorant of our own desires. We assembled the programme by feeling our way through and listening to ourselves, choosing projects capable of granting us an experience of a total shift in perspective. Or, more accurately, capable of revealing realities of the most varied nature undetectable at first glance. For instance, the manifestation of women’s invisible labor in the film industry is the subject of the theatrical/artistic laboratory Vokrug da Okolo’s production Movie Ticket, the site of which will logically be Lenfilm Studios, where female co-workers and co-creators (not muses) worked unseen alongside the great masters of the craft. Pyotr Kurkin’s School Simulator will send the audience to a class and recess, allowing them to feel those countless strings that bind classmates together and which forever bind us (whether or not we want to admit it) to our classroom desks and the ring of the school bell.

In the programme of reenactments of famous performances (Vanya Demidkin and Artyom Tomilov’s Unexpectedly Wonderful), acts well-known to us from recent art history resonate in a completely different way with today’s reality. Or maybe not. None of the eight acts will be announced in advance, so as not to anaesthetize the audience’s perception. Ilya Moshitsky’s production Flights will be a journey without borders, a trip into ourselves capable of revealing our unconscious impulses, those hidden under the weight of civilization. The Norwegian director and actionist Morten Traavik’s exhibition project PARTY SONGS will let us peek into the world’s most closed-off country, North Korea. Is it worth mentioning that upon close inspection, even that country isn’t at all what it seems? Festival-goers can look for the protagonists of Ksenia Peretrukhina’s projects in parks: tiny vandals (Bad Little People) and giant elderly people living out their warm, fuzzy lives in ease (Weekends Come but Once a Week). In the project tentatively titled Rosa, Sergei Chekhov and Rosa Khayrullina will call the laws of thermodynamics into question: the actress’s body will come into contact with cosmic energy, casting light on the dark areas of the most precise science (although things might go differently in what is so far the most mysterious project in the festival programme).

Last year’s festival took place entirely online, but the 2021 programme features productions that exist both on the internet and in the real world, opening up different degrees of immersion.  Each project that presupposes physical participation will have a digital double that will eliminate the need to overcome geographic distance. The main programme doesn’t have any headliners; all the projects are a mutual risk. By request of The Access Point, the young directors are doing things they’ve never done before (with the exception of Morten Traavik, but that’s another matter entirely). We hope that both in the programme’s organization and in how the various roles are distributed within each team, our intent of encouraging a lateral structure are clear. Each project is the result of a coordinated effort from all the participants, making it possible to eschew a strict hierarchy and repressive work methods in the artistic process. If this is possible in the theatre, then perhaps it might be possible outside of it.

children: The festival provides special conditions for professionals: actors, directors, producers, curators, concept makers, art critics and all those who work in cultural institutions. You can buy a ticket for the events of the Main Program of the festival at a fixed price of 350 ₽ (one guest can get no more than 2 such tickets) or a subscription for the entire program at a reduced price of 3000 ₽ (the number of subscriptions is also limited).
To apply for a season ticket or promo code, please contact us info@tochkadostupa.spb.ru.
Are you a journalist or a critic?

To get accreditation for performances and other events of the festival, send an application to the mail pr@tochkadostupa.spb.ru. In the application, you must specify your name, the publication that you represent, the name of the play you are interested in, the date of the show and the time.

If there are no available seats for the selected show, we will find an alternative solution together with you. Please note that the earlier you tell us your intentions, the more likely we will be able to create a comfortable schedule for you. Accreditation for any event of the festival is closed 3 days before the show date.
To find out the news of the festival before anyone else, subscribe to our newsletter on the main site.

ON THE EDGE – online event

The internet becomes the festival’s space. The Access Point launches a Spontaneous Programme of online productions, inviting everyone interested in investigating communication in the pandemic to present their projects. The Educational Programme features leading artists from Europe, North America and Australia.

The festival features two concurrent tracks: the curated projects that form its Main Programme, and its Free Programme of almost 30 fringe productions, performances and installations. The large-scale Educational Programme now consists of more than public lectures — it also includes a series of closed, hands-on group classes with leading theatre instructors from Italy, Denmark and USA. The results of these classes are workshop productions made by those in attendance.

At the time Russia’s only festival/co-producer, The Access Point presents three of its own productions, made in conjunction with Germany, Switzerland and Iran. Productions from Tatarstan and Australia are featured. In addition, the festival hosts its first laboratory.

The festival opens in the Russian Museum with a large programme dedicated to the 100th anniversary of the October Revolution. The festival becomes international and begins receiving support at the federal level from the Union of Theatre Workers of the Russian Federation.

The festival brings together mostly St. Petersburg-based artists (actors, directors, playwrights and set designers), inviting them to view the urban landscape as a theatre space. Theatre productions and contemporary art are presented equally. Over 100 short films from various countries make up its large film programme.

The festival is inspired by the contrasting urban environment of St. Petersburg and the variety of textures in its outskirts. The emancipation of the theatre form echoes the emancipation of the way the audience is engaged. Shows are performed in a factory, a residential neighborhood, a department store during working hours and a library.
